Darkonius 03-Feb-19 04:23 AM
@SirWayNe @Bluebird I have a lot of experience with runes. `SetRuneSpawnTime does nothing btw. gamemode:SetUseDefaultDOTARuneSpawnLogic(true)works if you want normal rune timings. gamemode:SetBountyRuneSpawnInterval(BOUNTY_RUNE_SPAWN_INTERVAL) and gamemode:SetPowerRuneSpawnInterval(POWER_RUNE_SPAWN_INTERVAL) are bugged. They both work for powerup runes and bounty runes (same spawn timings). gamemode:SetRuneSpawnFilter(Dynamic_Wrap(your_gamemode_name, "RuneSpawnFilter"), self)` didn't work the last time I tried. Manually spawning dota runes is impossible (reasons why below). Making custom runes on the other hand is possible. (edited)
1
* dota_item_rune entities are some special entities, they are not items or npcs !!! * GetName() works on rune entities but returns nothing * with GetModelName() you can find out what rune it is (model names can be found in assets browser) * GetOrigin() and SetOrigin() work on rune entities, * Spawning rune entity with SpawnEntityFromTableSynchronous("dota_item_rune", { model = "", origin =}) works partially and ONLY for double damage.
@Deleted User there is abilitytunefilter, with it you can change values of abilityspecials
Deleted User 03-Feb-19 04:33 AM

Darkonius 03-Feb-19 04:33 AM
it worked last time I tried it

Darkonius 03-Feb-19 04:34 AM
its commented out because its useless in most cases

UniBridge BOT 03-Feb-19 07:03 AM

Perry 03-Feb-19 07:03 AM
lua abilities and modifiers can have client parts
for example
you have a lua modifier giving 20 MS
if you wrap the entire thing in IsServer(), it will work fine, but the bonus wont show up on the UI
if you wrap nothing in IsServer, you will probably run into some API that is not supported on the client
since the client has a lot less priviliges than the server

UniBridge BOT 05-Feb-19 04:50 AM
<Timmeh42> is there a guide to what DynamicWrap does?
Quark 05-Feb-19 04:50 AM
you can find the code for it somewhere in the dota folders
UniBridge BOT 05-Feb-19 04:51 AM
<Timmeh42> well, i dont even know what its meant to do tbh
Quark 05-Feb-19 04:56 AM
----------------------------------------------------------- -- A function to re-lookup a function by name every time. ----------------------------------------------------------- function Dynamic_Wrap( mt, name ) if Convars:GetBool( 'developer' ) then assert( mt ~= nil ) --assert( mt[name] ~= nil ) local function w(...) if not mt[name] then error( string.format( "Attempt to call %s which is undefined", name ) ) end return mt[name](...) end return w else return mt[name] end end
Perry 05-Feb-19 05:05 AM
Timmeh42: basically if you put dynamic wrap around a callback it will reload it with script_reload
UniBridge BOT 05-Feb-19 05:05 AM
<Timmeh42> so thats for reloading scripts in game?
Perry 05-Feb-19 05:05 AM
so if you do ListenToGameEvent("npc_spawned", DynamicWrap(GameMode, 'OnNpcSpawned'))
then every time you reload it will use the latest reloaded version of OnNpcSpawned
UniBridge BOT 05-Feb-19 05:13 AM
<Timmeh42> are you able to dynamicwrap other entity events, or just gamemode events?
Perry 05-Feb-19 05:15 AM
you dont actually need to dynamicwrap other stuff
as long as you do the if modifier == nil then modifier = class({}) end
instead of modifier = class({})
Keril Artemov 05-Feb-19 05:16 AM
Dynamic wrap is meh
Perry 05-Feb-19 05:17 AM
really you dont need to do any dynamic wrapping
UniBridge BOT 05-Feb-19 05:17 AM
<Timmeh42> ah so thats what the if modifier == nil then stuff is
Perry 05-Feb-19 05:17 AM
if you use the if thing == nil
and you dont directly reference functions
you can reload without any dynamicWrap
UniBridge BOT 05-Feb-19 05:18 AM
<Timmeh42> so if u do that, script_reload works anyway?
<Timmeh42> neat
Perry 05-Feb-19 05:18 AM
yeah
the important thing to remember is
ListenToGameEvent("npc_spawned", GameMode.OnNpcSpawned) will register that actual function as callback
then if you reload it is still registered to that function
if you do ListenToGameEvent("npc_spawned", function() GameMode.OnNpcSpawned() end) it will evaluate what the latest function is when it's called
also it's important that GameMode stays the same thing (hence the == nil)
otherwise again it will bind to the old version

Elfansoer 05-Feb-19 11:53 PM
well, if I use script_reload or cl_script_reload, the lua tables were reset, right?

Keril Artemov 05-Feb-19 11:53 PM
not on existing entities
Just think of this modifier as a flag which is automatically synchronized
What script_reload mostly does is just it runs your code once again
There is some special behavior with lua abilities but not sure what happens exactly
On reconnect it's different
With script_reload there are things to reload
With reconnect there is nothing to reload, you have to reconstruct the whole state from 0
Elfansoer 05-Feb-19 11:56 PM
well, as far as I was testing, that happened. All lua tables are reset as u said, run through the codes, replace previous instances. Isn't that the same thing as starting from 0? Regardless, I've been avoiding that for a long time. I would have to face it some time, but, ehhh.... later. Either I'm too lazy or just didn't give any pleasure at writing such code
Keril Artemov 05-Feb-19 11:56 PM
Not the same
see for example
function create_dog() end
is the same as
create_dog = function() end
it's imperative instead of declarative
when you script_reload your code just runs again but the global state is old (edited)
what makes it renew is those imperative statements
like when your mod is first ran the global table _G is empty { }
then it encounters function create_dog() end
and then it becomes _G = { create_dog = function() end }
when you script_reload it also tries to write create_dog into the _G
and rewrites the old one
that's why for example if you remove the create_dog function and script_reload you will still be able to call it
and that's why instead of doing my_players = { } function on_player_connect(player) table.insert(my_players, player) end which will reassign my_players on script_reload to an empty table
you could write
if my_players == nil then my_players = {} end function on_player_connect(player) table.insert(my_players, player) end
so my_players is only initialized on the first load
Perry 06-Feb-19 12:01 AM
Timmeh42 ^
Keril Artemov 06-Feb-19 12:01 AM
and all script_reloads will encounter that my_players is not nil and will not reinit it
Elfansoer 06-Feb-19 12:01 AM
wait. still digesting
So basically the difference is that recon == empty global table, while script_reload== previous global table. Is that so?
Perry 06-Feb-19 12:05 AM
yes
Elfansoer 06-Feb-19 12:05 AM

Perry 06-Feb-19 12:06 AM

Darkonius 08-Feb-19 05:24 AM
@Deleted User `function HasBit(flags, specific_flag) return bit.band(flags, specific_flag) == specific_flag end`
usage: HasBit(behaviour, DOTA_ABILITY_BEHAVIOR_NO_TARGET )
